I never thought companies like General Mills, Verizon, the Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones and now Coca-Cola would invite me to speak about grief and loss to their employees and leadership. They clearly want to invest in creating a supportive environment for their entire team. We know that as leaders, we must be grief-informed in order to show support when times are good and when we are struggling with difficult times. 
I’ve been speaking about grief for decades and remember a time when grief was a taboo topic. My audiences were made up mostly of healthcare professionals, mental health experts and first responders. They always knew the profound impact grief can have on individuals. Now more corporate leaders are understanding that when a team member's loved one dies, it is the ultimate employee engagement. 
In the workplace we acknowledge births, engagements, weddings and birthdays. We now know that if we want to have healthy organizations, workplaces, families, congregations and schools, we must talk about grief in the workplace also.
The Coca-Cola company recently brought me in to give talks and a podcast. I appreciate them taking such a leadership role in engaging with their employees in such a profound way.
Happy to share that Coca-Cola podcast with you click on the button in bio. If you have experienced grief, how well did your work handle it?

Do we celebrate birthdays after a loved one dies?  For the bereaved, that’s an individual decision.

I spent the weekend at Graceland where Lisa Marie Presley, a bereaved daughter and bereaved mother, invited me to share in the weekend celebration of her father’s 88th birthday. Of course, in death, he had more people at his birthday party then many do in life.

For those in the public eye, we often acknowledge these milestones and talk about how old they would be today if they had lived. These public displays of affection for those who are famous and have touched our hearts are widely accepted. This should also be the case for our loved ones who we love and miss. We should normalize what people in grief are doing and feeling privately already by acknowledging birthdays. I often will have a cupcake, or a piece of cake and light a candle for my son David on his birthday. Do you mark your loved one’s birthday?.
.
.
.
#grief #griefjourney #griefsupport #griefawareness #griefeducator #lisamariepresley #graceland #elvispresley #grievingprocess #lossofafather #lossofachild #davidkessler

I’ve been so fortunate to have Lisa Marie as a friend. Her bold, authentic personality made her a loyal daughter and devoted mother. The loss of her son inspired her to work toward becoming an advocate for those who are struggling with the heartbreak of grief.

I met Lisa Marie after her son Ben died. She wanted to talk to me, not because I was a grief expert, but because I was someone who also had a child die. It became an improbable friendship but that is how grief works. 

Last weekend, she asked me to go with her to Memphis for her father’s 88th birthday celebration. She had countless invites for the weekend, but for her, there were only three important ones: being at her father’s birthday celebration, spending time at her son and father’s grave after the tours left Graceland, and meeting with a recently bereaved mother. 

I watched how Lisa Marie tenderly talked to this heartbroken mother about what to expect in grief. That's what interested her most these days, helping others in grief.

She had her challenges but always faced them. She was in my grief educator program and many who met her and chatted with her had no idea who she was. To them, she was a mother, whose son had died and wanted to turn her pain into purpose. She co-led grief groups with me for the past two years at her home for other bereaved parents. We were planning on doing a podcast about grief together. Her family, love for music, maintaining her father's legacy, and helping others became her priorities.

Last weekend was so much fun and she was optimistic. Graceland was her happy place and the employees who all knew her shared that she was looking so much better. She looked more at peace and was so proud of the Elvis movie.

Saturday night we sat at the graves of her father and son. We talked about the heartbreak she grew up with and the more recent devastation of her son’s death. She showed me where she would be buried someday. I said a long time from now …and she said yes,I have so much to do.

Rest in peace with your father and son, Lisa Marie.

pic taken of us last weekend at Graceland 

#lisamariepresley #lmp #elvismovie #graceland

Over 2700 mental health care professionals gathered at the Psychotherapy Symposium 2023 in Washington DC.  When I first had the honor of presenting there over 10 years ago, we would be assigned a room that fit the interest in our subject. My 2 hour talk was in a small converted hotel room with 7 people. The next year 20 people, then 35, then 70 and so on. 

The other day my talk was an all day session with 650 clinicians in person and 700 virtual. I believe that growth is about the world becoming more grief literate and clinicians realizing that their education was lacking in grief and they wanted to provide the best care for the clients they serve. So many leaders in this field are present Bessel Van Der Kolk, Deran Young, and Lori Gottlieb.  And two amazing main-stage speakers Alanis Morissette and Dick Schwartz. I loved meeting some of our grief educators and Tender Hearts members in-person!

#NetworkerSymposium #pns23 #psychotherapynetworker #RichSimon

Free online event today!

Grief hurts. When a friend, family member, or client is in grief, it’s so hard to know what to say or do. All of the platitudes and clichés may sound hollow at times. People mean well, but some are grief illiterate. We want to hold a light in the darkness and help others. 

I want to share with you what I have learned over the past 40 years of helping others with grief in a free online event so that you’ll know how to support others in their darkest days.

Helping with Loss: Addressing the Six Needs of Grief

March 21st, 12 pm PT/ 3 pm ET

In this teaching, we'll discuss how to:

-Help others who have suffered even the most tragic losses
-Learn the 6 needs of the grieving so you can help others navigate grief
-Encourage post-traumatic growth to move beyond the pain and create a legacy of love
- Inspire others to identify reserves of resilience that may surprise them

I’ll share the tools you need to confidently help others navigate the rocky terrain of grief.

Register below to reserve your space. Please feel free to forward this along to any colleagues or friends who you think might find it helpful.

Link in bio 

https://www.davidkesslertraining.com/helping-with-loss-event

I am so proud of the Grief Educator Certificate Program graduates. I love hearing about all the amazing ways they have found to bring help to the world. 

Never has there been a moment when those who are in the depths of grief could use more support. As a Certified Grief Educator, you will have the exact roadmap to confidently guide people to create a full life that honors their loved ones. 

Let’s start a movement of helping!

I am leading a Grief Educator Certification training.

In this training, you’ll learn the roadmap to compassionately and effectively coach others in grief:

✅ Get an In-depth understanding of death, dying, trauma, and grief

When you have the right tools and the experience to confidently guide people in grief not only will you see their lives dramatically change, but when you’re living your purpose you will experience the fulfillment that comes from knowing that helping truly is healing.

social_posts.post_text:
Pre-grief is real - Roman Roy of HBO Max series’ Succession is on to something. As a grief specialist, I can tell you that he is correct!

Roman Roy asked in the last episode if perhaps he may have “Pre-grieved" his father’s death. When it comes to feelings in the show, it's often hard to establish authentic emotions. Succession is far from the healthiest representation of grief. Yet, the truth is there is “pre-grief” My co-author, psychiatrist, Dr Elisabeth Kübler-Ross originally called this preparatory grief. We later wrote about it again in our book. We called it anticipatory grief. That is the name it is commonly known as now. Anticipatory grief is the grief you feel before the death. We know someday our parents will die, but when a life threating diagnosis happens, it becomes a very real experience. Most of the time in grief we are focused on the loss in the past, but in anticipatory grief we occupy ourselves with the loss ahead. 

We often think of the anticipatory loss occurring for the dying person, but many times loved ones go through them ahead of the death also. This is especially true in long drawn-out illnesses such as terminal cancer, dementia and many others. Even if you go through anticipatory grief, you will still go through grief again after the loss. 

Anticipating a loss is an important part of experiencing that loss. Such anticipation may help us brace ourselves for what is to come, but we should be aware that the anticipation of an event may be just as powerful as the event itself. 
 
For those who experience a sudden death they often feel robbed of the experience of anticipatory grief. Forewarned is not always forearmed. Experiencing anticipatory grief, may or may not make the grieving process easier or shorten it. As Roman Roy says, it may eventually crush him like a freight train. Whether or not that will be true in the series Succession remains to be seen. However, grief often turns out to be bigger than expected and often feels crushing. Have you experienced anticipatory grief?

#succession #SuccessionHBO #successionhbo #grief #griefandloss #griefeducator #davidkessler #davidkesslergrief #griefsupport

I was so humbled and honored to present the @afspnational - Survivor of Suicide Loss Lifesaver Award to Ashley Judd to recognize her efforts in savings lives and bringing hope to those affected by suicide. I remain in awe of her turning her pain into purpose and helping so many. 

I couldn’t describe the evening as well as Ashely herself so I wanted to share Ashely’s personal description of the night from her Instagram post - @ashley_judd 

“A beautiful, tear and laughter filled night as my Chosen Family, partner, David Kessler, Bono, and many others showed up for Mom and me as American Foundation for Suicide Prevention recognized me with their Life Saver Honor. A distinction none of us would never desire, I accepted it on bloody knees as I have crawled through this year of grief and love, discovering with trauma-informed help the wisdom of wounds. Mom would have been proud of the joke I opened with - she always began with a joke when spoke - and being in the company of illustrious researchers and advocates who were also lauded for their indefatigable efforts toward alleviating the suffering of mental illness and reducing stigma. It was a gorgeous room, the wait and janitorial staff did such an impeccable job, everyone was so kind and warm. Thank you for holding space for us and making an unforgettable memory. I especially appreciate my Chosen Sisters (of which this is just a sampling) for being in NYC for my big week - arranging time away, organizing childcare, financial investment, emotional labor, and most of all, for simply loving me. I love you, too, so much” – Ashley Judd

Thanks Cindy Hsu from @CBSNewYork led the evening. I remain grateful CEO Robert Gebbia and Christine Moutier and congratulate the other award recipients Doug Middleton, Madelyn Gould, Ph.D., MPH, and Rory O’Connor @suicideresearch and @afspnational Audacy with the Public Education Lifesaver Award at this year's Lifesavers Gala. 

Please join us all in raising awareness, raising money for prevention and after care, talking about suicide even when it makes others uncomfortable. We must end the stigma and shame.

Join me on this replay episode of my Spotify podcast. In our experiences of grief, guilt can play an outsized role. So today, I speak to two members of my online grief group, Tender Hearts, who are both deeply immersed in guilt. “If only my boyfriend and I weren’t on a break, I could’ve saved him…” “If only I hadn’t let my son go outside, the tragedy never would’ve happened…” These are hard conversations. This time of year, I always think about Saint (Mother) Teresa.  I will always remember when she told me the dying and people in grief need tender, loving care - nothing more.

People often tell me they are trying to help their friend/family member and nothing is working. I’ll say, Have you tried just loving them? They'll respond with, “Yes but I need to go to a group or they need to see a counselor or they need to move on.”

I will say, That’s not “just loving” them, that’s conditionally loving them. Can you just unconditionally love them?

I love this picture of us in Calcutta. I will always be deeply grateful to her kindness and help in the beginning of my career.  She remains a beacon in my heart and soul to always lead with kindness.
.
.
.
.
.

What is Baby Loss Awareness Week?

Baby Loss Awareness Week is a chance for people who have lost a baby to come together as a community and find a supportive space to share their experiences. 1000s of people each year experience baby loss in pregnancy, at or soon after birth, or in infancy. However, there is still silence, shame and discomfort around the topic.

When is baby loss awareness week?

Baby Loss Awareness Week 2023 takes place from 9th October to 15th October.

The history of Baby Loss Awareness Week

Baby Loss Awareness Week, now in its 21st year, began as a way to connect people who have lost babies in order to provide support and community.

As the day has risen in importance, many baby loss charities have stepped forward to help spread the word and engage people all over the world. 

Just know in our tender hearts sessions, we have a group for this on Mondays.

People not in grief often want to compare losses.  Comparing is of the mind. We don’t have a broken mind, we have a broken heart. For those in grief who feel the need to compare all their own losses, why do we need to choose? And if we compare to others and say ours is the worst, it often is a way of saying our grief has not been witnessed enough. All our tears count.

The reality is the more we can address our own grief and trauma, the more we can have compassion for others
.
.
.

The holiday season is upon us. It’s a time reserved for joy and togetherness, but for those grieving the loss of a loved one, it can be a challenging season. Beyond our own grief, it can be difficult to support our friends and loved ones who have experienced a loss. How can we come together this holiday season to offer healing and support?

I recently spoke with renowned grief expert and author @IAmDavidKessler on the #CelebrationsChatter podcast to learn what we can do to help ourselves and others as we move through grief. As Founder of grief.com, David’s work impacts millions of people worldwide every year. We touched on practical aspects of grief, covering everything from comforting the bereaved to creating a supportive environment at work. Most importantly, David shared some valuable perspective on finding meaning in loss, which can be especially challenging during the holidays.

Listen to the full episode at the links in our bio, and leave us a message - How do you cope with grief during the holidays? What ways have you found to support colleagues, friends, and family? Share your thoughts on how we can navigate this season together with empathy and understanding.

Our loved ones absence is very loud during the holidays. Cheering up grievers doesn’t work, accepting and loving them does. Thoughts?
If you are experiencing grief, check out our free video on Thanksgiving and grief, visit link in bio www.holidaygrief.com

Grief is a deeply personal experience that varies from one individual to another. But amidst these diverse experiences of loss, a common thread binds us - the universal need for our grief to be seen and acknowledged. It's not about comparing sorrows or measuring pain; it's about recognizing and respecting each person's unique journey through grief. In understanding this, we can offer support and empathy, helping each other navigate the waves of loss with compassion and care.

In grief, hindsight can be a misleading guide, leading us to believe we had more control over past events than was truly possible. This misconception often intensifies our pain, as we find ourselves grappling with the endless "what-ifs" and burdened by guilt. 

A step towards healing is recognizing that hindsight only offers an illusion of power, one that we never actually had. It's through this understanding that we step towards releasing ourselves from the guilt that encompasses our grief.

Grief requires us to courageously face and experience our pain, because avoiding it only prolongs our suffering. By embracing our emotions and allowing ourselves to feel deeply, we navigate through the darkness toward a place of love. This journey, though challenging, is where true healing and understanding begin. Let's treat our pain with the compassion and patience it deserves, recognizing it as an essential step in our journey toward healing.

Healing is a transformative journey, not about erasing our past but embracing it with kindness and understanding. It's about recognizing that while our experiences shape us, they don't have to confine us. In healing, we don’t try to erase our memories; instead, we learn to take the love born from them and infuse our lives with their warmth, allowing us to feel enriched, not encumbered.

What are your thoughts?

Writing is a powerful tool in healing. Your story is important and is as unique as you are. Grief expert David Kessler and writer/editor Andrea Cagan are leading an inspiring and supportive 5-week course to walk you through the healing process of writing. 

Comment "WRITE" below, and I will send you a link to register for the workshop!

In Writing Through Loss and Trauma you’ll experience:

👉 Weekly Zoom writer’s workshop with David and Andrea
👉 Access to a training platform with weekly video teaching 
👉 Writing prompts and exercises
👉 An online community to share your work and get feedback
👉 Tools to help write about difficult times without getting stuck in the pain
👉 Share your work and get feedback
👉 Support to gain more confidence and clarity in your writing
👉 Bonus meetings with an award-winning grief writer and a literary agent to help you take the next steps in your work

We’ll go beyond the nuts and bolts of writing to learn strategies to share our most tender stories without getting pulled back into the pain of the past. We’ll help you find your authentic voice and experience writing prompts to help bring out the salient details and capture the heart of your story.

I would love to have you be a part of this.

In grief, we all seek to be seen, not for others to diminish our pain or change its narrative, but just to be present in our loss. True comfort lies in someone acknowledging our sorrow and standing with us in these moments without trying to "fix" our pain or flood us with toxic positivity. There is nothing to fix and no silver lining in the loss of our loved ones. 

Do you agree? What are your thoughts?
